comment.author: 72646284@N00
comment._content: The Flyer on the flag mentions: Rev Anna Shaw digital.library.upenn.edu/women/eagle/congress/shaw.html Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt (who somewhat resembles the person on the left in this picture) en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carrie_Chapman_Catt And quite possibly mentioned Max Eastman en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_Eastman

comment._content: Same women as this photo and others--just a different pose: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2478433644/ Jessie Stubbs, Rosalie Jones, and Ida Craft (in that order, here).

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Thanks for deciphering the flyer!  We'll add that info and the women's names, then reload the description.

comment.author: 23186536@N08
comment._content: Speaking at the suffrage meeting advertised on the flier seen here, Carrie Chapman Catt has a close connection to International Women's Day (IWD). In 1904, she was elected to the first board of the International Woman Suffrage Alliance at a meeting in Berlin and reelected in 1906 in Copenhagen. She promoted suffrage for women in her travels around the world in 1911-1912, stopping in South and East Africa, the Middle East, India, China, and many other places.
